Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, the hum of conversation swirling around me as my stepdad passed the salad and my stepsister recounted her day. My phone buzzed quietly in my lap—a new pharmacy newsletter notification. I knew I should be present, laughing at my stepbrother’s jokes, asking about my stepmom’s new job, but my mind kept drifting to the headline: “Critical New Drug Approvals This Month.” As a pharmacist, I was expected to stay sharp, always up-to-date, and I felt the weight of that responsibility. But here, as a step-sibling, I was supposed to be part of this family, to show I cared, to help us all feel a little less like strangers. My stepmom caught my eye, smiling, and I felt a pang of guilt. I wanted to be both—engaged family member and diligent professional—but the demands pulled me in opposite directions. My thumb hovered over the newsletter link, heart pounding, as laughter echoed around me.
